title: Clarity Act Stalled! What This Means For Bitcoin & Crypto

chunks.text:
Okay, our pump slightly stalled. And the reason 
why our pump slightly stalled—because we're still   at 96,755—the pump slightly stalled because the 
discussions around the Clarity Act stalled. I   think we need to talk about the Clarity Act and 
what the stall actually means because it is the   single most important piece of legislation for 
crypto globally, not only in the US. I know it's   a US piece of legislation, but it is the single 
most important piece of legislation for crypto   globally. Yesterday, the discussions in the Senate 
around the Clarity Act stalled. So, we need to   discuss exactly what happened, why it happened, 
what it means, which tokens it's going to effect,   and whether your bags are actually safe. That's 
what I'm going to break down for you today. I'm also going to show you why I think the pump 
is going to continue. Another big show today,   I've really got a lot of stuff going 
on. It's a big, big, big show. Let's go. All right, let's get going. Wakey, wakey. Rise and shine, guys. I see you all in the   chat. Everybody's here again. Glenn Goldberg is 
here as usual. Wife Changing Money is here as   usual. Davis Jansen's here. Everybody's here. We're going to talk about a lot of things,   including the pump. You know my feeling around 
this pump is very simple, right? You mustn't cry   because it's over; you must smile because it 
happened, guys. Don't cry because the pump's   over. Smile because the pump happened. That's 
Dr. Seuss, in case you don't know that. We're   going to talk about the pump and exactly why 
it stalled. It stalled because the discussions   in the Senate Banking Committee regarding the 
Clarity Act stalled. They were stalled primarily   by Coinbase. I'm going to show you why. It seems 
like it's a Coinbase thing and not an industry   thing. I'm going to show you exactly why I think 
it's happening. Who's being protected? Who's not   being protected? Hint, hint: the big banks are 
there. Hint, hint: Elizabeth Warren's there. Big show. Listen guys, I see everybody here. I 
see a lot of people are starting to come back. Thank you to all of you for helping us by 
hitting the like button because you guys are   bringing back all our old friends and they're 
all coming to hang with us again. Please help,   just smash the like button. If you're 
not subscribed, subscribe to the channel. Though most people are already subscribed. You 
guys are already part of the fam. As I said,   I think we need to talk about this pump. As I said in the beginning of the show,   don't cry because it's over; smile because it 
happened. Right now, if I look at this pump,   we are above that key area. We're at 96,000 
and 97,000. Remember, we had such a bad year   last year. It was an embarrassing year for crypto 
because we ended in the midst of a correction. But   because we started off on such a low level—we 
started the year off in the 90,000s—so far,   we are actually the number four best-performing 
major asset this year. It's a small victory   because we came from a very low base, but there 
is a lesson there. The lesson is that if you   come from a low base, you're due a catch-up 
trade. It makes for a very, very good year. That's one of my theses around what's going 
to happen this year. I think Bitcoin is going   to be touted as one of the best-performing 
assets this year. Not only because it's a very   good performing asset, but more importantly 
because it came off a low base and because   fund managers artificially measure returns from 
one period to another. That's what I made a video   on Crypto Insider about. I spoke about this and 
said we're going to have a big catch-up trade,   maybe not because of the performance of the 
asset, but because we're going to start off a   low base. When you start off a low base, people 
start to look at you and say, "Well, what's the   best-performing asset this year?" They're going 
to see things like the fact that right now Bitcoin   is the best-performing asset. Then they're 
going to say, "Wow, can you afford to not be   invested in the fourth best-performing asset? I mean, you're invested in silver, platinum,   palladium. How can you afford not to be invested 
in Bitcoin?" That's exactly what's happening. In fact, if you look at what Eric Balchunas 
said—I really love this tweet—he said,   "Bitcoin ETFs had their biggest day yesterday, 
$843 million of inflow. The one week now is at   a billion and the year to date is at 1.5 billion.

and said we're going to have a big catch-up trade, maybe not because of the performance of the asset, but because we're going to start off a low base. The one week now is at a billion and the year to date is at 1.5 billion. Bitcoin sitting at a price of 97,000 after being   at like 88 for what seemed to be like half a year. It feels like maybe the buyers have exhausted the   sellers. We'll see though. I do know that if we 
hit 100K, some people are going to gnash their   teeth so bad that they should probably go ahead 
and buy a free mouth guard. Peace and love." It's   a tweet which sounds kind of weird, but that's 
how investment psychology works. If something is   moving up from a calendar date, then people say, 
"Wow, we should be invested in it." Right now,   Bitcoin is the fourth best-performing asset. The 
best-performing major asset this year is silver. The good news is that we opened up a silver 
bot on Pionex. For those who don't know,   Pionex is a place where you can trade with 
bots. This wallet has been going with $50,000   since before October 10th and it's at 
$133,000, which just shows you how well   the bots can trade without the humans. You 
can also open bots on silver, copper, gold,   and all the commodities. I'm not going to spend 
too much time on the bot on this show, but if   you want to join a free Discord group, it's free. It's where we post all the bots because we just   wanted to separate the bot traders from the main 
show. There's a link in the description below. Just go to the description below and you'll 
see a link to the free Discord where you can   basically just sign up. It's over here. Just 
sign up to the free Discord and you guys can   get all of it, including the silver bot, 
the gold bot, the Apple bot, stocks, etc. So, the pump basically continues. We've 
broken a whole lot of crucial levels;   a lot of crucial levels left to go. I think the 
most important thing here is the following: Number   one, the ETF buyers are back. You can see over a 
billion this week. Number two, the yield is coming   back. The yield is very important because the 
yield on an annualized basis shows us the demand   for Bitcoin perpetuals, which is an important 
measure. It shows you the risk appetite in the   market. The main thing that I'm seeing here is 
that the takers are the dominant buyers. There's   a taker seller and a taker buyer here. Right now, 
the buyers are ruling the market. We are being   set up for another short squeeze. You have an 
interesting funding setup. The price is going up,   but the funding is going deeply negative. This 
means that as we go up here, people are going   short. That could cause a short squeeze. I 
suspect that as we get to $100,000, we're   going to see the mother of all short squeezes. That's going to take us all the way up above. But anyway, for now, our pump is slightly 
stalled. Not a lot. It's 96,400. Much honor. Oh,   who blessed that? As I mentioned to you, the 
reason why the pump stalled is because of   the Clarity Act and the fact that the discussions 
in the Senate Banking Committee failed. Now,   for those who are not American or for those of 
you trying to understand why this Clarity Act   is so important, let me give you the rundown. It 
is the single most important piece of legislation   of all time. Why? Because a lot of countries 
are waiting to see how America regulates crypto   before they regulate crypto. Also, America is 
one of the big countries where crypto has to   be accepted because the US dollar is the reserve 
currency in the world and the US is probably the   biggest country in the world. In order for this 
piece of legislation, which is the second piece   of legislation to go through... The first piece 
of legislation was the Genius Act.

that? As I mentioned to you, the reason why the pump stalled is because of the Clarity Act and the fact that the discussions in the Senate Banking Committee failed. Now, for those who are not American or for those of you trying to understand why this Clarity Act is so important, let me give you the rundown. It is the single most important piece of legislation of all time. Why? Because a lot of countries are waiting to see how America regulates crypto before they regulate crypto. Also, America is one of the big countries where crypto has to be accepted because the US dollar is the reserve currency in the world and the US is probably the biggest country in the world. In order for this piece of legislation, which is the second piece of legislation to go through... The first piece of legislation was the Genius Act. Someone said,   "Much honor." You guys remember much honor? These 
are for the real old people that have been here. So, the Clarity Act is the second piece of 
legislation. The Genius Act really spoke about   stablecoins. The Clarity Act is literally designed 
to give people clarity about crypto. It's to give   people clarity about DeFi, clarity about what 
you can and can't build as a developer. It's   around investor protections. It's pretty much the 
one act that is going to make crypto mainstream. The reason why that's so important is because 
there are a lot of corporations and a lot of   real money, sovereign money, and state money that 
can't invest in crypto or can't invest in certain   sectors of crypto until there is certainty about 
what crypto actually is. And when I say crypto,   I'm talking about crypto, not Bitcoin. Because 
for all intents and purposes, people know how   to deal with Bitcoin. So, the Clarity Act is 
actually much, much more. It is for Bitcoin   because Bitcoin is obviously the bedrock of the 
industry, but it's much more for altcoins. The   problem with altcoins is that we don't really 
know what's legal in the US and what's not. We   don't know how to deal with DeFi. We don't 
know what we can pass interest rates on. We   don't know what we can develop. That's not really 
a Bitcoin thing; it's much more an altcoin thing. It is the single most important 
piece of legislation. The process   for it to get passed as law: it has to go 
through the Senate Agriculture Committee,   the Senate Banking Committee, and then it has to 
go for the final vote in the House. Now where are   we? The Senate Banking Committee decided to pull 
tomorrow's scheduled market structure following   drama with Coinbase. It seems that Coinbase 
has a problem with this bill. Brian Armstrong   tweeted, "After reviewing the Senate Banking 
Committee draft text over the last 48 hours,   Coinbase unfortunately can't support the 
bill as written. There are too many issues,   including a de facto ban on tokenized equities, 
DeFi prohibitions, giving government unlimited   access to your financial records, and 
removing your right to privacy." Read   that word "privacy" because we're going to talk 
about it later. "Erosion of the CFTC's authority,   stifling innovation and making it subservient 
to the SEC. Draft amendments would kill rewards   on stablecoins, allowing banks to 
ban their competition." He says,   "We appreciate all the hard work by the members to 
reach a bipartisan outcome, but we'd rather have   no bill than a bad bill. Hopefully, we can get 
a better draft and we'll keep fighting for it." Important for you to notice that the one party 
that's very much against this is Coinbase. There   are many other parties that are actually very 
much for this, including Andreessen Horowitz,   Kraken, Ripple, Paradigm, and Circle. Not only 
that, other people that are for it: XRP, Ripple,   Chris Dixon from Andreessen, Arjun from Kraken, 
but also Vlad from Robinhood. They're all looking   specifically at what they want. So Vlad's looking 
at staking, saying, "Look, staking is one of the   most requested features on the Robinhood app, 
but it's still unavailable to customers in the   US due to the current gridlock. Stock tokens 
are available for our customers in the EU,   but not in our home market. It's time for 
the US to lead on crypto." He's saying,   "Let's pass legislation, protect consumers, 
and let's get the show on the road." Chris Dixon is basically saying, "Crypto builders 
need clear rules for the road. Over the past 5   years, Republicans, Democrats, and the Trump 
administration have worked closely with members   across the board to protect the industry. At 
its core, this bill does that. It's not perfect,   and changes are needed before it becomes 
law. But now is the time to move with the   Clarity Act."

also Vlad from Robinhood. They're all looking specifically at what they want. Stock tokens are available for our customers in the EU, but not in our home market. It's time for the US to lead on crypto." He's saying, "Let's pass legislation, protect consumers, and let's get the show on the road." Chris Dixon is basically saying, "Crypto builders need clear rules for the road. Over the past 5 years, Republicans, Democrats, and the Trump administration have worked closely with members across the board to protect the industry. At its core, this bill does that. It's not perfect, and changes are needed before it becomes law. But now is the time to move with the Clarity Act." They all want the Clarity 
Act to move. Everyone wants it to move,   but Brian Armstrong is the biggest opponent saying 
we cannot sign this act into law. Remember that   everyone here is protecting their interest. I don't think this is a perfect bill by any   stretch of the imagination. From what I've read, 
it's not good for tokenization. It doesn't protect   developers against developing things, which 
is quite a problem. But the main problem here,   and the reason why Coinbase is pushing back, 
is about this issue on stablecoins. If it   wasn't for this issue on stablecoins, 
things would be completely different. Now, why is Coinbase fighting so hard on this 
stablecoin thing? And if you want to read between   the lines, why is Circle actually agreeing with 
this bill? Circle is actually in support. What's   going on here? Well, what I think a lot of you 
don't know is that Coinbase makes a lot of money   from a distribution agreement with Circle. They 
are a distribution platform for USDC. That's where   most trading pairs are done, USDC trading pairs. Coinbase is a massive distributor for Circle and   Coinbase makes money from Circle through this 
thing called a USDC economics agreement. In 2024,   Circle paid Coinbase almost a billion 
dollars tied to USDC distribution economics. Analysts also noted that Coinbase earned 
roughly 300 million in just Q1 of 2025 from   these distribution payments. How the split 
works: Coinbase receives 100% of the reserve   interest income from the USDC held on Coinbase 
and a 50/50 split of the reserve income off the   platform. In other words, if there are USDC coins 
sitting on Coinbase, which are your USDC coins,   Coinbase is earning 100% of the interest income, 
which is at government yields of 4% and 5%. In the new proposed bill, the problem is that 
one of the things around stablecoins is that   you may not share the revenue on stablecoin 
interest. That is the biggest thing that I   think Brian Armstrong is fighting against. The real fight here isn't between Circle   and Facebook. The real fight here is the banks. The banks want to make sure that the stablecoin   business doesn't replace them. Listen to what 
Brian Armstrong said here: "Well, in that case,   I think that's just the banks trying to 
protect their profit margin. They should   have to pay rewards and higher rates to their 
own customers. I think they're trying to put   their thumb on the scale of regulatory capture 
essentially to prevent crypto from doing that. But my prediction is actually the banks are going 
to start... we're already seeing this actually,   they're going to be increasingly embracing 
stablecoins. My guess is that in a year or   two they'll come back and say actually we want to 
be able to pay interest and yield on stablecoins   in our own companies. It goes back to that 
innovator's dilemma situation. The best banks are   leaning into this as an opportunity and the ones 
who are fighting it are going to get left behind." The whole argument is about the fact that 
Coinbase pays 400% more interest than a typical   bank on a bank account. Let's look at what that 
actually means. When the bank takes your money,   the bank invests that money into treasury 
yields and they earn about 4%. So, you put   $100 into the bank deposit. The bank invests that 
money in treasury yields or lends that money out   and they pay you 0.39%, which is less than 10% 
of the profit that they earn. With stablecoins,   you don't need a bank. You can put your money into 
USDC and earn 4% just by holding the stablecoin. The bank doesn't like this because effectively 
what it's doing is cutting out the entire   banking system model. That is what the 
banks are trying to protect against here.

an opportunity and the ones who are fighting it are going to get left behind." The whole argument is about the fact that Coinbase pays 400% more interest than a typical bank on a bank account. Let's look at what that actually means. When the bank takes your money, the bank invests that money into treasury yields and they earn about 4%. So, you put $100 into the bank deposit. The bank invests that money in treasury yields or lends that money out and they pay you 0.39%, which is less than 10% of the profit that they earn. With stablecoins, you don't need a bank. You can put your money into USDC and earn 4% just by holding the stablecoin. The bank doesn't like this because effectively what it's doing is cutting out the entire banking system model. That is what the banks are trying to protect against here. Here is a letter urging the senators to close 
the stablecoin loop, written by the Bankers   Association of America. It says, "The Genius 
tax, while not perfect from a community bank   perspective, was a reasonable attempt to bring 
stablecoin into market regulation. Among the   most important provisions is a ban on interest 
payments that was put in place to ensure that this   new payments market can develop maturely without 
becoming a competitor to bank deposits. Under   the law, stablecoin issuers cannot pay interest 
because allowing inducements like interest, yield,   or reward could incentivize customers to park 
their savings not in a bank, but in a stablecoin. Congress recognized that this could significantly 
disrupt community lending because banks could   use those deposits to provide individuals and 
businesses with loans that they need to expand." The banks are basically saying, "Look, if 
you allow this, then people won't put their   money into the bank and therefore we won't have 
banks to help the businesses of America." Well,   innovate your business model! Because here you 
can put your money into a stablecoin and get 4-9%. The banks want to say, "No, we want to take your 
money, deposit it at 4%, and fund our expenses." This big stall is about the interest rates. Rest 
assured, everything else can be negotiated. Circle   doesn't mind. I believe Circle has an agreement 
with Coinbase, but if the legislation says Circle   can't pay Coinbase a distribution fee, Circle 
will go, "Damn, Coinbase, we can't pay you. But that means we just make another billion 
dollars because we're not allowed to pay you." The real fight here is actually against the 
traditional banking system. We should be   fighting the traditional banking system here. It's no surprise that the person most lobbied   by the banks is Elizabeth Warren. She's filed 
38 amendments to the bill, including removing   developer protections, more sanctions, compliance 
obligations, more illicit activity checks, etc. She's fighting this bill because we know she's 
always the one fighting for the traditional banks. Where are we at now? The discussions have stalled, 
but it's not unusual for discussions to stall   while people take a breath, regroup, renegotiate, 
and come back with slightly different drafts. Polymarket is still predicting a 60% chance that 
this bill is going to be passed by the end of   the year. Which is good. It's the highest it's 
been in a long time. It dropped as low as 41%,   and now it's on the way back up. Most opinions 
I've seen are saying they're all negotiating in   good faith and think it will happen. Mike 
Novogratz said, "While the bill might be   delayed to keep working, I'm confident we'll 
get the bill passed. I've spoken to over 10   senators on both sides of the aisle and I believe 
they're all working together in good faith." Senator Cynthia Lummis didn't want to comment 
on Coinbase's opposition, but when asked if it   would impact the process, she said, "I think 
it'll have a profound impact on the process." I asked ChatGPT, "Why is Coinbase so important 
to this process?" ChatGPT said Coinbase is the   proof that crypto can be regulated. They're the 
most regulated player in crypto. If they say   the legislation doesn't work, then the legislation 
doesn't actually work. Also, they are probably the   biggest political donor to this movement. We need 
them to pass. It's very important we get this act   passed very soon. Number one, we may be going into 
another government shutdown. Number two, we need   to get this piece of legislation passed before the 
midterm elections. Right now, the Republicans are   in the House and they own the Senate. There is 
a 78% probability that the Democrats will win   the House in 2026. If the Democrats win the House 
in the midterms, this legislation ain't passing. Who is the person most incentivized in the 
entire world to get this passed?
